docs.lead_paragraph: A new study provides evidence that a pregnant woman can consume moderate amounts of caffeine without impairing her baby's growth and development. The new findings add to a body of conflicting research that explores the effects of caffeine on the developing fetus.

headline.main: Conflicting Views on Caffeine in Pregnancy

docs.abstract: New study provides evidence that pregnant woman can consume moderate amounts of caffeine without impairing her baby's growth and development; new findings add to a body of conflicting research that explores the effects of caffeine on developing fetus (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Seated Yoga,'' with Carol Dickman, Yoga Enterprises, $19.95 for VHS (43 minutes), (888) 937-9642 or www.stretch.com. ''Sitting Fit Anytime,'' with Susan Winter Ward, Yoga for the Young at Heart, $19.95 for VHS (43 minutes), (800) 558-9642 or www.yogaheart.com. For a nation of couch potatoes, here comes the ultimate workout: seated yoga. Seated yoga is not as lazy as it may seem, however, because the cure lies or, for that matter, sits, in the cause: too much sitting creates aches and pains. But doing yoga while sitting heals them. New Age logic, to be sure, but the exercises in ''Seated Yoga,'' featuring Carol Dickman, and ''Sitting Fit Anytime,'' with Susan Winter Ward, are surprisingly effective. And relaxing. ''If you focus 100 percent on what you are doing, you will receive 100 percent of the benefits,'' advises Ms. Dickman, a woman who would have us all be impressively polite to our body parts. ''Invite your head to start to move,'' she intones. ''Allow your eyes to close.'' As for our shoulders, we ought to ''invite them to remain relaxed.'' ''Invite your entire body to relax,'' she proposes. Wholeheartedly taking her up on the invitations, I promptly fell asleep. I had been performing the postures, or exercises, on my bed, so much better for sleeping than my chair at work, my car, a bus, my sons' hockey arenas or any of the other places I could be sitting and doing yoga. On awakening, I am happy to report, I heard Ms. Dickman soothingly command, ''Let go of any judgments,'' for then I knew that she would never judge me harshly for slipping into slumber. And who was I to judge anyone, anyway, especially since my head was spinning from the neck-circles as well as from the accolades on the video box by that renowned yogi Raquel Welch, who gushes that the lithe, dark-haired Ms. Dickman is ''endlessly resourceful and an excellent coach.'' For me, endlessly resourceful and excellent is an exercise called the Mess Around, in which you make circles with your torso, loosening up all those limbs and whatnot. Other stretches untied the knots, accumulated from hunching over my computer keyboard, that were holding my neck and upper back hostage. Ms. Winter Ward, whose long gray hair is as wiry as her body is agile, directs her video to ''beginners, baby boomers and seniors.'' In ''Sitting Fit Anytime,'' which might be subtitled ''And Anywhere,'' we are asked, ''How much time do we spend sitting each day?'' Plenty! So don't just sit there! Roll your head, your hips, your ankles. Sitting, she says, puts stress on your lower back. The solution? Stretch. Arms up, reach for the sky. Put one ankle over your knee and stretch forward. Lace your fingers between your toes and squeeze. And, of course, breathe. I'm not quite sure what my boss would think if I suddenly sat back and shot my legs way up in the air, but I know my hamstrings would be delighted.

headline.main: No Yoga Studio Nearby? Your Chair Will Do

docs.lead_paragraph: By early next year, infant formulas sold in this country may have had an important change in their ingredients. The Food and Drug Administration has just approved the addition of two fatty acids that can enhance the neurological and visual development of children who are not breast-fed. These fatty acids, which are naturally present in breast milk, are already being added to formulas in 60 countries and have been endorsed as beneficial to infant development by the World Health Organization.

headline.main: An Enriching Change for Infant Formulas

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column welcomes FDA approval of two new ingredients for infant formulas, the fatty acids DHA and AA, saying they can enhance neurological and visual development of children who are not breast-fed; says products may be on market by early 2002; DHA and AA are manufactured by Martek Biosciences Corp (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kathleen DeSormier, a 39-year-old woman from Tiverton, R.I., has had diabetes since she was 22, and for many years she needed three shots of insulin a day to control her blood sugar. Although she got used to the injections, the routine was still tiresome. ''Sometimes the shots hurt, and you have to rotate injection sites,'' Ms. DeSormier said. ''You tend to fall into a routine of going to the same spot and build up scar tissue.''
docs.abstract: Diabetes patients in clinical trials are able to cut back their daily injections of insulin, controlling diabetes by using insulin inhaler; at least three inhaled products are being studied, along with spray that is absorbed through lining of mouth; none have been approvewd by FDA, but if studies succeed, a noninjected form of insulin may reqach market in two or three years; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''When the Road Turns: Inspirational Stories About People With MS,'' by Margot Russell. Health Communications Inc. $12.95. Writing about multiple sclerosis, the chronic neurological disorder that can impair movement and coordination, is no easy task. For one thing, this debilitating disease varies in symptoms and severity from person to person. Making matters worse, the underlying cause is unknown, and a drug that seems to help one person may not do much for another.

headline.main: Patients Define M.S. in Their Own Words

docs.lead_paragraph: Does growing up with parents who are gay or lesbian make a difference? A host of studies published over the last two decades would argue that it does not. These studies, cited in custody disputes and drawn upon by lawyers arguing for same-sex marriages or gay adoptions, have for the most part concluded that no important distinctions could be found between children raised by homosexual parents and those raised in more traditional homes, each with one mother and one father.

headline.main: A Rainbow of Differences in Gays' Children

docs.abstract: Two sociologists challenge prevailing notion based on studies over two decades that children growing up with parents who are gay or lesbian are no different than children raised in more traditional homes; Dr Judith Stacey and Dr Timothy J Biblarz, both of University of Southern California, contend that social scientists have found provocative differences but have played them down for fear that findings will be misused; contend that while there is no evidence that having gay or lesbian parents harms children, notion that it has no impact on child's life is implausible at best; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Does growing up with parents who are gay or lesbian make a difference? A host of studies published over the last two decades would argue that it does not.    These studies, cited in custody disputes and drawn upon by lawyers arguing for same-sex...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a discovery that is capturing the attention of experts on mad cow disease, an Israeli scientist has reported finding a unique substance in the urine of people and animals afflicted with various forms of the malady. The substance -- a small, never-before-seen protein molecule -- may be a clear marker for mad cow disease and related ailments, a group of illnesses called prion diseases. Its presence in urine could lead to a simple test for mad cow disease and its human form, called variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The only definitive test now is a brain biopsy, which is rarely done; most cases are verified only after death.

headline.main: A Marker for Mad Cow Disease May Be Found in Urine

docs.abstract: Dr Ruth Gabizon of Hadassah University Hospital in Jerusalem finds unique substance in urine of people and animals afflicted with various forms of mad cow disease; substance--a small, never-before-seen protein molecule--may be clear marker for mad cow disease and its human form, called variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Physicians, like most human beings, often judge people based on fleeting or even mistaken impressions. But in medical practice this habit can have decidedly negative effects on diagnosis and treatment. Sometimes, when doctors don't believe there's a real disease underlying a patient's complaints, we label that person harshly as a malingerer or a ''crock.'' Such troubled souls do exist. They may not have an organic disease, but they do possess an alarming psychic need to consult physicians and weave complex tales of phantom aches and pains. There is even a vast amount of medical literature on the topic.
docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel article on challenges facing physicians with patients who complain about this or that but have no underlying disease; says in his experience, malingerers are rare (M)
